questions.text: A 35-year-old patient was referred to Surgery OPD from obstetrics OPD when an adrenal gland mass was detected on an Imaging. The patient is apparently asymptomatic. On probing, a previously occult endocrine disturbance came to light. What is the most common functional tumor found in this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cushing’s Adenoma The case scenario describes an incidentaloma . An incidentaloma is an adrenal mass, detected incidentally by imaging studies conducted for other reasons, not known previously to have been present or causing symptoms. Cushing's Adenoma has a 7% prevalence Prevalence of non-functioning and functioning tumors in patients with incidentalomas Tumor Prevalence (%) Non-functioning adenoma 78 Cushing's adenoma 7 Adrenocortical carcinoma 4 Phaeochromocytoma 4 Myelolipoma 2 Cyst 2 Metastases 2 Conn's adenoma 1

Highyeild:

Cushing's adenoma is a type of benign tumor in the pituitary gland that causes excessive production of ACTH hormone. It can cause a wide range of symptoms including weight gain, muscle weakness, high blood pressure, mood swings, and thinning skin. DiagnTreatment osis involves blood tests and imaging tests like MRI or CT scan. involves surgery, medication, or radiation therapy.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Conn's adenoma has a 1% prevalence Option: B. Phaeochromocytoma has a 4% prevalence Option: D. Adrenocortical carcinoma has a 4% prevalence

Extraedge:

With appropriate treatment, most people can achieve complete remission of their symptoms. Risk factors include genetics, hormonal imbalances, and pituitary tumors. Complications can include osteoporosis, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and increased risk of infections.

questions.correct_answer: B. Discontinue ACEI > Biochemical tests > Thin-slice CT > Adrenal Venous Sampling.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Discontinue ACEI > Biochemical tests > Thin-slice CT > Adrenal Venous Sampling. The most common causes of primary hyperaldosteronism are unilateral aldosterone-producing adenomas ( Aldosteronomas ). In primary hyperaldosteronism , the goal of diagnostic testing is to identify and lateralize aldosteronoma. Discontinue ACEI > Biochemical tests > Thin-slice CT > Adrenal Venous Sampling is the most appropriate order of investigations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with hypertension was found to have hypokalemia, on further evaluation he was found to have raised the aldosterone to plasma renin activity ratio. The CT scan was non-lateralizing. The aldosterone to cortisol ratio (ACR) was not significantly different on both sides. What is the best course of treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Spironolactone The patient is being worked up for primary hyperaldosteronism. The insignificant difference in aldosterone to cortisol ratio (ACR) , points towards non-lateralizing adrenal lesions (bilateral adrenal hyperplasia) causing primary hyperaldosteronism(PHA). The first-line therapy for PHA with bilateral hyperplasia is a medical treatment with spironolactone and salt restriction. In most cases, supplemental antihypertensive medication is necessary to achieve satisfactory control of blood pressure.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Unilateral adrenalectomy is done for asymmetrical disease. Option: C. Subtotal adrenalectomy is done in the case of a typical single conn’s adenoma. Option: D. Diuretic of choice is Spironolactone.

Extraedge:

Primary hyperaldosteronism is most commonly caused by a benign tumor called an aldosterone-producing adenoma, but can also be caused by hyperplasia (overgrowth) of the adrenal gland. To diagnose primary hyperaldosteronism, doctors may also perform a salt loading test or captopril challenge test to confirm excessive aldosterone production. There are two subtypes of primary hyperaldosteronism: aldosterone-producing adenoma and bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. These subtypes require different treatment approaches.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presented to the clinic with complaints of pain in the abdomen and weight gain. The patient was found to also have hypertension & abdominal striae. Biochemical tests showed raised cortisol levels and Phaeochromocytoma was also ruled out. On further evaluation, an adrenocortical tumor measuring 4 cm was found on the left side. All of the following factors point towards malignancy in this case, except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High cortisol levels Adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC) is a rare malignancy with a variable but generally poor prognosis. Criteria for malignancy are tumor size, the presence of necrosis or hemorrhage, and microscopic features such as capsular or vascular invasion. These should be assessed in terms of a microscopic diagnostic score.

Highyeild:

Adrenocortical carcinoma Adrenocortical carcinoma is a rare tumor, with more than half of cases being functional. Cushing's syndrome is the most common functional presentation, followed by virilization. Microscopically, adrenocortical carcinomas are characterized by hyperchromatic cells with large nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Distinguishing benign adrenal adenomas from carcinomas by histologic examination alone is difficult; capsular or vascular invasion is the most reliable sign of cancer. Adrenocortical carcinomas almost exclusively occur in patients aged 40-50 years with no gender predilection. At initial evaluation, these tumors are usually very large (mean size 9-12 cm). Metastases to the lymph nodes , liver , and lungs may be found.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Tumor size is a criterion for malignancy. Option: C. Presence of necrosis or hemorrhage is a criterion for malignancy Option: D . Capsular or vascular invasion is a criterion for malignancy

Extraedge:

Surgical resection is the mainstay of treatment for localized disease, but the prognosis is generally poor for advanced or metastatic disease. Adjuvant therapy with mitotane, a steroidogenesis inhibitor, may improve outcomes in some patients, but its use is controversial and limited by toxicity. Multidisciplinary management is recommended for optimal diagnosis and treatment of adrenocortical carcinoma.

questions.text: Phaeochromocytoma is a tumor that most commonly produces supraphysiological levels of circulating catecholamines. It was classically known as the ‘10% tumor’ because of the following factors, except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

10% occur in adult Sporadic phaeochromocytomas occur around the fourth decade, whereas patients with hereditary forms are diagnosed earlier. 10% occur in children . Phaeochromocytoma is known as the ‘10% tumor’ as 10% of tumors are inherited , 10% are extra-adrenal , 10% are malignant , 10% are bilateral , and 10% occur in children .

Highyeild:

Pheochromocytoma is a tumor that originates from chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla and other sites. It has a peak incidence in the 4th and 5th decades of life , with no gender predilection. The most common site of an extra-adrenal tumor is the organ of Zuckerkandl. An extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma is also known as a paraganglioma .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . 10% of phaeochromocytomas are extra-adrenal Option: B. 10% of phaeochromocytomas are malignant Option: D . 10% of phaeochromocytomas are bilateral .

Malignant pheochromocytomas are more likely to express p53 and bcl-2 and have activated telomerase. questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with hypertension and headache; he was found to have tachycardia & his BP was 150/100mmHg. Biochemical & Imaging showed a Phaeochromocytoma of size 4cm. What is the most appropriate treatment protocol?

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.correct_answer: C. Phenoxybenzamine > Propranolol > Volume repletion > Laparoscopic Adrenalectomy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phenoxybenzamine > Propranolol > Volume repletion > Laparoscopic Adrenalectomy The medical management of pheochromocytomas is aimed chiefly at blood pressure control and volume repletion. Irreversible, long-acting α-blockers such as phenoxybenzamine are started 1 to 3 weeks preoperatively at doses of 10 mg twice daily β-Blockers such as propranolol are often added preoperatively in patients who have persistent tachycardia and arrhythmias . β-Blockers should only be instituted after adequate α-blockade to avoid the effects of unopposed α stimulation. Patients also should be volume repleted preoperatively to avoid postoperative hypotension, which ensues with the loss of vasoconstriction after tumor removal. Adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice for patients with pheochromocytoma. Most pheochromocytomas < 6cm in diameter can be safely resected laparoscopically. The open anterior approach is only used: For the detection of bilateral tumors, For operating extra-adrenal lesions, or In metastatic lesions

Highyeild:

Medical Management of Pheochromocytomas: Alpha and beta blockers used to control hypertension and prevent hypertensive crisis during surgery. Alpha blockers used first to prevent vasoconstriction, followed by beta blockers to prevent tachycardia and arrhythmias. Alpha blockade titrated over several days to weeks for adequate blood pressure control. Caution exercised when adding beta blockers to avoid unopposed alpha stimulation. Intraoperative management may require additional medication. Postoperative monitoring and tapering of medications necessary to prevent rebound hypertension and hypotension.

Random:

Explanation For All Options:- Option: A. Pheochromocytomas < 5 cm in diameter can be safely resected laparoscopically Option: B. β-Blockers should only be instituted AFTER adequate α-blockade Option: C. It is the most appropriate protocol. α-Blocker > β-Blockers > Volume Repletion > Laparoscopic surgery Option: D . Propranolol should be started after α-Blocker & Prazosin is usually used for long-term management.

Extraedge:

Intraoperative management of hypertension and hemodynamic instability may require additional alpha and beta blockade or the use of other medications such as nitroprusside, nitroglycerin, or magnesium sulfate. Postoperative monitoring and gradual tapering of alpha and beta blockers are necessary to prevent rebound hypertension and hypotension.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman was referred to the surgery OPD after she was suspected to have phaeochromocytoma. Which of the following description of the biochemical tests and imaging studies done for diagnosis & localization of Phaeochromocytoma are TRUE? 24-hrs Urinary VMA/Metanephrines are the most reliable tests available today. Plasma-free metanephrines testing has the highest sensitivity. MRI is also the study of choice in pregnant women 131-Iodine-radiolabeled MIBG is useful for localizing pheochromocytomas especially those in ectopic positions. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, 3, and 4 are correct The first step in the diagnosis of a phaeochromocytoma is the confirmation of excessive catecholamine levels. The biochemical diagnosis is then followed by the localization of the pheochromocytoma. MRI is preferred because contrast media used for CT scans can provoke paroxysms.

Highyeild:

Investigations for diagnosis of pheochromocytoma: The most sensitive screening test is the measurement of urinary catecholamines and VMA levels. The best test for diagnosis is the measurement of fractionated plasma metanephrines. MRI is the imaging of choice for detecting adrenal and extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma and is particularly useful in pregnancy. MRI has a sensitivity of 95% and specificity of 100% for pheochromocytoma. CT scan should be performed without contrast administration to prevent the hypertensive crisis. MIBG scan is helpful for extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma , but MRI is still the preferred imaging modality for extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma as well.

Random:

Explanation For All Statements:- Statement 1. Measurements of 24-hour urine levels of metanephrine and normetanephrine level are still the most reliable tests available today. Statement 2 . Plasma-free metanephrines testing carries an extremely high sensitivity, approaching 99%, and being a one-time blood test, it is more convenient than 24-hour urine testing. Statement 3. MRI scans are 95% sensitive and almost 100% specific for pheochromocytomas because these tumors have a characteristic appearance on T2-weighted images or after gadolinium. MRI is also the study of choice in pregnant women as there is no risk of radiation exposure. Statement Metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) is taken up and concentrated by vesicles in the adrenal medullar cells because its structure is similar to norepinephrine. Normal adrenal medullary tissue does not take up appreciable MIBG. 131I-radiolabeled MIBG is, therefore, useful for localizing pheochromocytomas in ectopic positions.

Solution:

Metyrapone > Anticoagulation > Unilateral Adrenalectomy > Cortisol Supplementation. questions.text: Match the following surgical options available for Adrenal Surgeries with the most. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2 The different Laparoscopic and open adrenalectomies/resections have separate advantages, use, and indications for them. Statement 1. Retroperitoneoscopic adrenalectomy has become the ‘gold standard’ in the resection of adrenal tumors. The advantage of the retroperitoneoscopic approach is the minimal dissection required by this extra-abdominal procedure. Statement 2. Laparoscopic Transperitoneal approach is more popular as it offers a better view of the adrenal region than open surgery. Statement 3. Open approach should be considered if radiological signs, distant metastases, large tumors (>10 cm), or a distinct hormonal pattern suggest malignancy. Statement 4. Small, bilateral tumor or in patients with hereditary tumor syndromes a subtotal adrenal resection is warranted, to avoid steroid dependence.

Highyeild:

Retroperitoneoscopic adrenalectomy offers a direct approach to the adrenal gland, has a shorter hospital stay, less postoperative pain, and results in smaller incision and less scarring. Transperitoneoscopic adrenalectomy provides a wide surgical field, can be performed with a small incision, and has a lower conversion rate to open surgery. Open adrenalectomy provides a direct view of the surgical site, allows for more precise dissection, and can remove lymph nodes for cancer staging. Subtotal adrenal resection preserves adrenal function, may be preferred in bilateral adrenal disease or when complete removal of the adrenal gland is not desirable, and has a lower risk of complications.

Extraedge:

Retroperitoneoscopic and transperitoneoscopic adrenalectomies are both minimally invasive laparoscopic procedures that offer faster recovery, less pain, and smaller incisions compared to open adrenalectomy. Retroperitoneoscopic adrenalectomy is preferred in patients with a history of abdominal surgery or obesity , while transperitoneoscopic adrenalectomy provides a wider surgical field and may be preferred in small adrenal tumors. Open adrenalectomy is still considered the gold standard for large or complex adrenal tumors, or when there is a high risk of malignancy.
